description: From Middle English chekmat, from Old French eschec mat, from Arabic شَاه مَاتَ‎ (šāh māta), from Persian شاه مات‎ (šâh mât, “the king [is] dead”).

entries.meaning: The conclusive victory in a game of chess that occurs when an opponent's king is threatened with unavoidable capture.
(figuratively, by extension) Any losing situation with no escape; utter defeat.

verbs.description: checkmate (third-person singular simple present checkmates, present participle checkmating, simple past and past participle checkmated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, chess) To put the king of an opponent into checkmate.
examples: That jerk checkmated me in four moves!

entries.meaning: (transitive, by extension) To place in a losing situation that has no escape.
